author: dragoaus
body:
In personal opinion, one of the major drawbacks is, that management can "juice" its salary and bonus by doing repurchases, since by doing repurchases, they increase the stock price (usually metric on which their Bonus is calculated).

Second major issue is that repurchases of stock robs company of valuable capital, that could have been invested in upgrading production process and R&D. This specially hurts manufacturing and R&D heavy companies. 
For example from 1995 through 2019 IBM spent $201 billion buying back its own stock. 
At one point, management of IBM was bragging, how R&D expenditure of IBM has been reduced, so he could have more profits and returns to shareholders (dividends and repurchases). This worked great in short run, but results are clearly visible now, IBM is shadow of itself, company that was leading Innovation for decades is now a service company. 
Management got its bonuses, shareholders enjoyed short-term gains, but in the end where left with shell of company.
This was not only reason for IBM issues, but contributed significantly.
For more recent example, check Boing and Intel, both wasted fortunes on buybacks. Both were cheered by Wall Street for it, but in reality, both companies underinvested in their future.
I am not against buybacks, only it needs to clear, there is no free lunch, especially not in R&D heavy Industries.

author: falconne
body:
If a big energy company was able to drive the cost of renewables down so much it crashes the green tech companies, then they wouldn't need to buy them out, discount or not, since that implies the big company has leapfrogged them in tech.

Thing is, innovation and engineering is hard. You can't solve every problem by throwing money at it. If you're coming in to a field 10 or 20 years behind in research, just being big doesn't mean you're going to catch up in tech just like that. Look at what happened to IBM in the face of upstarts like Microsoft, Google, Amazon, etc.

Even if big companies can fund their own research later, that will put them a decade or more behind. Meanwhile, another big energy competitor could buy up several successful startups and quickly become the dominant player. So like with tech startups, the big players won't be looking for discounts, they'll just wait to see who makes the best proven breakthroughs and then compete with each other to acquire the best tech first.

author: TradingDaze
body: Sears used to sell house kits. They were most certainly into every aspect of your life.  People marked on their calendars when the new catalog would come.  The old would then be used for toilet paper. Like most of the mighty companies there was a change and they didn’t adapt. The internet should have turn them into Amazon but instead crushed them to nothing.   Digital photos killed a photo company that began with K.  The list goes on.  The point is good companies can stay good until some change rocks the business’ foundation and they adapt or die.   What will be the change for apple who knows but the fall of mighty tech companies happens (think IBM) but it’s usually a long slow decline.

author: dragoaus
body:
This is true for some companies like (Coca Cola, McDonald's, Banks and similar service oriented companies), which dont have large R&D expenditures, while having enormous positive cash flows and have enough money to support buybacks.

On the other hand, IBM is best example of company that completely underinvested, it missed Cloud (now dominated by Microsoft and Amazon), so clearly there was enough place to grow. Plenty of other areas in IT that were growing like crazy, that IBM completely ignored.

GE is another good example, Jack Welch gutted the company, turned it from manufacturing giant to financial company, and effectively run the company to the ground (Wall street was happy with dividends and buybacks). At same time Danaher (once called mini GE), was able to grow like crazy in same industries that GE discarded. Today Danaher is larger than GE.

author: exe_virus
body:
Big tech will be regulated to hell. Maybe not now, not in 5 years. But it will be anti monopoly regulated until a new crop emerges and overtakes. 

Happened with AT&T bell in the 60's which led to IBM, AMD, Texas instruments, etc.

Then in the 80's/90's, antitrust threats is what led these large hardware companies to outsource their software OS to Microsoft and apple and Unix. 

Then in the 2000's we had Microsoft Monopoly broken up and the dot com crash, which led to Google, myspace, etc. Then in '08 google and Qualcomm and all these technologies came together to form what allowed today's JavaScript web based companies like Facebook, YouTube (google), linkedin (Microsoft) you get the idea. 

What has allowed big tech to stay on top is *acquisitions*. When that power is taken away, you will see big tech's investment thesis fall apart. And lo and behold that's the kind of anti monopoly regulations we are starting to see.

author: lostinspace509
body:
Hi

I was thinking back at AAPL stock in the 1990s when they were struggling to survive after Microsoft and IBM got the personal PC out.  AAPL would have been almost a full checklist on your list, but they got one product out there (the i-pod), home run.  Then they got another one out there (the i-phone), then wow, they took over the world and the second golden age is here.

I agree, with most of it.  I just think that we simply need to add that some companies may be down but not out.  We need to do all that work you suggested (Kudos, this shows my age), but we also need to realize that companies can re-invent themselves and come back.  If so, I would like like such a "fool" by passing on it, would I not?

I think if I could say something definitive is, you are right most of the time and then sometimes there is that one..... and damn, we missed it.. lol

author: OrangeDutchy
body:
The private space sector is just getting started. It's such a young company ,14years so it doesn't even have a driver's license. Speaking of which consider Ford going public in '56, look at all those decades of building up before going public. Or IBM over 100 years ago. 

So profitability, being so young its all about scaling up and expanding their facilities. Any money is being used to make them more competitive. They believe they can do that by building a larger rocket which will broaden their capabilities. They will be receiving a 750million dollar cash injection. 200 of which will be going to designing and building the next rocket [Neutron ](https://youtu.be/agqxJw5ISdk). Give them room to screw up and lets put it at 250. The rest of the money could go to a number of things. Building a launch pad in New Zealand for Neutron, they have a deal to use the existing launch pad in Wallops, Virginia. They could build three more Neutron rockets, you could have a fleet. Cycling one out and brining in a new improved model throughout the years. They also have their own unique satellite bus built in-house, [Photon](https://youtu.be/LAUj-TQpn-A). First it delivers the payload of other satellites, but it's also open to configuration. I hope they have plans on scaling that up for the Neutron.  They are currently generating revenue, but no they are not cash flow positive, they hope to reach  that in a couple years.

Sustainable, as a private company they made it through the global recession of 08(I know that's a weak point). Their still acquiring more partners as they continue to develop their product. For instance BlackSky started by launching their prototype with another launch provider, but now they have multiple launches contracted with Rocketlab. 
This is still a young industry, if the speculation about mining in space comes true, I believe they will be well positioned for that market. In the mean time it's all about satellites. I think we're at a crossroads, the infrastructure on a large scale could be changed. Do we continue laying and maintaining ground lines to connect everyone on the network? Or do we launch a bunch of satellites and change so everyone goes back to putting a dish on their roof? Or Winnebago, and have internet in the middle of nowhere?

Scaleable, I've already hinted towards scalability with a fleet of larger rockets. Possibly larger satellite busses. But it's space, so I want you to use your imagination and think if it's scalable.

author: SirGlass
body:
Yes historically I could see a reason to collect dividends trading fees were high, some brokerages charged extra fees for odd lots some only sold lots of 100 at a time.

So if you had stashed away 100k in IBM stock in the 1990s collecting $500 in dividends every quarter was free. You could get a check mailed to you. Selling $500 of stock every quarter would cost you $35-60 in trading fees what is like 10% fees. Collecting a dividend was a free way to sell and bi-pass trading fees.

Now the fees are so low or almost nonexistent the benefit of selling is you have the choice when/how much to sell. A dividend is a forced taxable event

author: Rodgerwilco
body:
TSMC supplies Apple, NVDA, Intel, AMD, Samsung, Qualcomm, IBM, Microsoft, Sony etcetcetcetc. They are responsible for over 70% of the words chips. Sure, we're investing in US production of chips but TSMC is strategic by keeping their most important/advanced nodes on mainland Taiwan.  

China wants Taiwan. USA and allies will back Taiwan because it's a matter of national security and it's in our best interest to not get fucked by China.  

You're right, TSMC the company is not monetarily 'worth' 5 Trillion right now. But what's the price tag of a country that 70% of the worlds chips rely on? What are the collective value of lives that will be lost over that war? It's worth more than 5T in my books.

author: FinndBors
body:
> This ain’t like 2000

In a ton of valuation metrics they are worse than any other time in history other than 2000. And when people think of 2000, they think of pets.com being ridiculous. Those shit companies were not in any index and pets.com was 300-400 million market cap at its peak (which it held for a very short time). You can equate pets.com to companies like NKLA which make gravity powered trucks. NKLA was ~ 30B market cap at its peak -- and it's still worth 5B+. Pets.com actually had a business / revenue, tons of SPACs are little more than post series A companies, all of them worth well over a billion.

The "real" megacap tech companies of 2000 were hewlett packard, microsoft, ibm, csco, intel, sun, compaq, etc. Their P/E ratios are much closer to the FAANGs of today. And most of the peak P/E ratios happened after a series of bad earnings.

The only thing that is legitimately different now than before is low interest rates. Which is why inflation / fed reaction is a genuine serious fear.

author: Mr_Dude12
body: I’m predicting that Tesla may be in for haircut once the everyone else starts to roll out their own electric cars. I cannot dismiss the ingenuity they have used to make a golf cart a true luxury car. Their weakness is business model, repairability is a nightmare, selling cars without key features then making by them subscription items? They are not cars, they are hardware with software licenses that are only profitable if you count the pollution credits sold.  Established carmakers won’t play these games, will have local service departments and build them to be a hat they are: cars. They have been doing it for a century. The chip shortages have made them focus on high end models, I kinda doubt they will start the base model production given the profitable high end models will bring. I see the brands that you know selling higher end, and coach built super high end cars. Once the patents begins to expire, we will see Chinese cars flood the low end with of the shelf tech. I am in on Nio and researching the Chinese makes that are actually producing and selling cars today. I liken it to the IBM computer “clones” of the ‘80’s. We will see compatible plug and play parts. Anyone research the scooter market? China has super factories that you can order any number of scooters, at any price point based on the quality of the parts specified, then slap your model name in them. ( check out AliBaba.com, buy a shipment, print your labels and poof, you are a scooter manufacturer). Trademarks? Pfft. We will see a flood of odd names sold over the internet just like you buy your Dell or off brand computers. Money will be in batteries, mining for rare earth metals, etc.

author: lattercat42
body:
Bitcoin is likely here to stay and will be like investing in gold. There are other cryptos out there that will serve as the backend of practical day-to-day transaction stuff. I’m think amp, matic, cardano and because of their household names maybe even meme coins like Shiba Inu or Safemoon or Dogecoin if they can get their act together and get some legit financial organization behind them. Stellar lumens also have interesting potential. I think there is (or was) IBM involvement in that. 

Bit issue with all these cryptos are stability relative to fiat currencies.  I can’t have a container of milk cost me $3 when I take it from the cooler and $6 by the time I get to the checkout and then $1.50 by the time I get to my car. Not good for the consumer or the supplier.

author: airelfacil
body:
Really a wait-and-see moment for Intel.

On one hand, they could go the way of AMD and see a comeback (better management, innovation).

On the other hand, they could go the way of IBM (fewer product sales, confusing majority market share with customer loyalty).

It should be noted that IBM is still a successful company. They still hold the majority market share for mainframe computers and credit card transaction machines (you may have noticed the IBM logos on those beige old-looking cash register machines, [example](https://i.ebayimg.com/images/i/140790671093-0-1/s-l1000.jpg)). However, this has not been helpful in growing their stock price (instead they have a very good dividend).

author: willfightforbeer
body:
But that's the point, Watson is just IBM's AI cloud services brand, not some meta-model. And matching the performance of the off-the-shelf ML packages from AWS/GCP isn't an accomplishment, it's just table stakes for offering that particular cloud service. All of those are the standard AI tasks that all the big cloud providers offer as pre-trained services, since they're easy to build out. 

Don't think of Watson as a model or computer, think of it as a division in IBM that builds AI products and has a mixed track record.

author: renatomello
body:
Not really a consideration at the moment, to be honest. At this point I'm considering either staying at academia or working on companies more focused on the software integration part. Not necessarily in that order.

At the moment I see a handful of companies ahead of them in terms of both software and hardware e.g. one can actually access IonQ's hardware using IBM's (open) software Qiskit on top of accessing IBM's harware. Also IBM is at least a couple of years ahead in its hardware scaling. Moreover I consider not a controversial statement to say that IBM's (and others') hardware platform  (superconducting qubits)  is inherently less difficult to scale than ion traps, making the playing field tilted away from ion traps (and photonics tbh).

&#x200B;

I hope they prove me wrong because that would mean extraordinary success to everybody involved in the field, but the odds are stacked against them.

author: kfuzion
body:
Short answer, yes that would work. But chasing stocks with high dividend yield is usually a bad idea. It can work sometimes, of course. But I'd strongly suggest looking at the holdings; oil companies, AT&T, IBM, lots of riffraff has high dividends but they could easily have low/negative real return over the next 10+ years.

Skimming the top 10 holdings of each - I'd go with VDADX over VHYAX. Dividend appreciation, dividend aristocrats, usually good choices. Even taking a stock like AAPL for example - if you bought it in 2013, you'd have a 5% dividend yield on your original investment ($13/share back then, $0.60 dividend now). If you bought XOM in 2013 in the $80s, you'd only be making about 4% on your original investment. In terms of total return, again you'd be better off with AAPL by a long shot. So going for quality matters.

author: LambdaLambo
body:
> Those shit companies were not in any index and pets.com was 300-400 million market cap at its peak (which it held for a very short time). You can equate pets.com to companies like NKLA which make gravity powered trucks. NKLA was ~ 30B market cap at its peak -- and it's still worth 5B+

That kinda helps my point though. NKLA tanked but it has no correlation to the overall stock market, and the whole stock market went up in fact. Same with the entire SPAC bubble. Yes it was a bubble, but it popped and the market moved on its way without missing a beat. 

> The "real" megacap tech companies of 2000 were hewlett packard, microsoft, ibm, csco, intel, sun, compaq, etc. Their P/E ratios are much closer to the FAANGs of today. And most of the peak P/E ratios happened after a series of bad earnings.

Even then the PE ratios are not the same. MSFT in it's peak in 1999 had a PE ratio of ~82, it now has a PE ratio of ~35. 

I'm not gonna say that *every* company today is fine. Many are not (including NKLA). But the 2000 was endemic throughout the market (i.e. say "internet" and stock 10x'd at ipo). Today the market is much more varied and plenty of companies trading at high multiples do so because they're growth is very real.

Sorta unrelated but I personally believe tech got an insane boost from covid which is/will be driving huge digitalization efforts and  accelerate growth for many saas/cloud centric companies.

author: De_Elevator
body:
IBM Watson is the marketing brand name IBM uses to sell a bunch of machine learning (AI) software services. The systems other people build for specific problems using those services, like this one for the stock market, may or may not be useful.

A lot of large companies try to throw a ton of money at R&D without any real strategy and then get outmaneuvered by smaller and savvier competitors. Ford, IBM, and GE are a few really good examples. They may be undervalued based on traditional metrics but if they're viewed as weak relative to their competitors the market isn't going to give a fuck.

author: matrixnsight
body:
Sort of. Anyone can make an android device. Only apple can make iOS devices. We saw how this played out in the PC space already - anyone could make a windows computer. 75% of the market now is Android. Apple is regaining small market share but it's just a cyclical oscillation that occurs due to all the other platforms dropping to zero in the last couple years. E.g. if 5% of Android users decide to give iPhone a try and 10% of iPhone users decide to switch to Android, iPhone still gains market share when it's far enough behind (so you get the feedback effect we see now).

The problem with closed platforms is they will eventually find themselves behind. There are just too many competitors - it's Apple vs. the world. Wearables, automotive, VR, AI capabilities... there are tons of ways the landscape is going to change in the next 10 years and it's highly likely Apple finds itself behind. Camera upgrades and poo emojis can only get you so far - eventually people don't need your new product.

Apple also charges a fee to develop apps. It's free on Android. On Android you can bypass the app store easily and download any app, even from a web address, on iOS it is a massive pain (we see this with fortnite).

Also we are at peak phones now - I only see downward pressure on margins due to the competition. Apple cannot get away with such high margins anymore - the only reason we don't see that (their margin is only slightly falling) is because they've added all these other high margin business to offset it (i.e. their services they've expanded in the last couple years). The reality is they're losing margin on their phones and they won't be able to hide that in their numbers forever (they certainly tried when they changed their reporting two years ago).

So those are my concerns with Apple. I always felt their original PE ratio was correct. Once Buffet got in on them they experienced PE expansion which is irrational IMO and I predict will correct itself at some point.

That's my opinion anyway. I think the market is really messed up right now based on bad speculation.

For reference, I'd say IBM, INTC, AAPL, and MSFT should be way closer in terms of PE than they actually are. Something more in line with reality would be IBM -> 10, INTC -> 14, AAPL -> 18, MSFT -> 22. MSFT and especially AAPL sitting at 30+ is just ridiculous, as is IBM hovering around 25. I don't think INTC is priced that unreasonably but it is compared to everything else right now.

> I have used both android and other OS's and I have found Apple to be the most easy for my work and personal life

This was true years ago. Not true anymore.

author: justsomescrub
body:
Not so much diversifying as just straight up killing it. Operating income rose 189% from 2019 to 2020 with eps up 604%. Q1 2021 operating income is up 266% and eps is up 232% from Q1 2020 and it isn't *just* higher margins; Total revenue in 2020 was up 45% from 2019 and Q1 2021 total rev Is up 92% compared to Q1 2020. Oh and the XLNX acquisition or whatever pending china approval.

  
AND there are some tasty insider whispers IF TRUE insinuating next gen GPU performance above and beyond what they expect from Nvidia. FULL STOP. Not at bargain price points, or for certain niche applications just straight up expecting to have the best GPUs on the market next gen. Nvidia having something spicy up their sleeve non-withstanding; you never know with Nvidia.   

  Add in plans to buy back 4 billion worth of shares over the next 4(?) Years with cash on hand and plans for 3nm production by 2024 and everything I hear about AMD makes me think up up up. They have new deals with Samsung for their phones and google/amazon for servers, to add to the pile of deals like making chips for Sony and Microsoft consoles. The future looks bright.

I put 90% of my account in AMD last month when they were hovering around 80$ without a single worry and I haven't unwound my position yet. Hoping for 2021 guidance to be adjusted from 50% to 75% growth to set this thing off again. Or merger approval, whatever comes first.

author: Phaiiroh
body:
AMD shareholders have agreed to acquire XLNX. Instead of paying with cash, they are acquiring the company entirely through stock. The two parties have agreed to a fixed ratio of 1:1.72 to do so. Meaning for every one share of XLNX owned you will receive 1.72 ish shares of AMD. Only if all necessary regulatory bodies approve the acquisition. Currently China is the last approval required until the merger can occur. Technically China can say no and AMD will most likely decide to not go on with the merger.

Because the acquisition is a fixed rate of shares. OP is staring at current market prices the value of one share of XLNX currently is cheaper than 1.72 shares of AMD creating a small discount. So if you were to buy XLNX in an attempt to buy AMD at a cheaper rate it could or could not possibly work out. It’s not a guaranteed thing.

body: i love $AMD, however comparing them to NVDA is not the right move. NVDA is a different beast in that they have the growth of AMD while having the stellar gross margins. Investors are willing to pay a premium for NVDA because of how stellar they are in printing cash and profits. That being said, AMD deserves to be priced closer to NVDA than Intel. I do not believe AMD and Su Bae are focused on catching NVDA, and are more concerned with taking market share from and crushing Intel. All the DDs written on here continue to ignore how important the Xilinx merger is. It was hated on by many, but Su Bae is no moron, she is strongly positioning AMD to dominate the CPU and Semi-Custom solutions. AMD will continue to make progress in the GPU and gaming market but the growth and tendies will come from expanding further into and dominating the server industry and building strong relationships that will establish profits for years, as well as expansion into 5g, aerospace and defense, and AI.

I added shares of XLNX around $115 (AMD equivalent of ~$73) back in May and it was the first time I added to my AMD position since the Covid bottoms (all of the rest of my shares were from 2016 and 2018).

I think AMD is valued more conservatively than the vast majority of other tech/semi companies, but I still think it's ahead of itself. I wouldn't buy it at these current levels, but I'm definitely not selling either (e.g. - I told my family it was safe to buy in May when it got down in the low 70s, but said not to buy above $78-80).

Peter Lynch would approve though given it's EPS growth % is greater than (or equal to) it's P/E multiple.

Do a deep dive of r/amd_stock if you're really interested in AMD--there's a lot of excellent content and some extremely informed people there (I honestly don't follow AMD like I used to b/c I have enough faith in Su/Kumar/Papermaster/Norrod/Wang/etc that I'm just letting my AMD ride and spending all of my time focusing on the rest of my portfolio).

author: lefty_vengeance
body:
What reason do you think this will moon.  I expect it was showing nice gains mostly because Xilinx merger felt imminent.  With today's news of China moving forward with phase 2 review, people are going to be much more inclined to take profits:

"SAMR's process involves up to three review periods: Phase One lasts 30 days, Phase Two lasts 60 days, and Phase Three lasts 90 days. The regulator decides at the end of each phase if it's ready to make a decision or if it will move on to the next phase."

So rather than thumbs up, we've got up to 60 days before China gives the go ahead (or delays another 3 fucking months if they so choose).

I don't see it starting to heat back up until a few weeks after earnings.  I predict it sees low 80s before then.

author: ConditionPrudent1648
body:
I totally recommend leaps options.

Firstly, I made most of my money from leaps.
Share price rises by 25%, my options will have at least 50% profit margin.

Secondly, my holding timeline for stocks is usually 6-12 months. So leaps is great for me 
For my kids, I will buy stocks as I am leaving it for them for the next 15-20 years.

Lastly, don't think u can use margin on options so it prevents me from over leveraging.

PS. I usually sell my options once it get 50% profit margin and move on. Reason is that for me to get 100% profit on options, I will need the stock to rise at least 40-50% which is not really realistic, especially when I have time decay playing against me.

I also buy leaps options on solid companies like Google, amazon, xlnx, baba, jd, Shopify, ttd, crm......etc
I try not to play with meme stocks or companies that do not show at least 4 quarters of profitability.

Best of luck!

author: ConditionPrudent1648
body:
I had some pretty decent results doing leaps call options.
Usually buy ATM call options expiring 200 days and above.

Usually chose blue chip companies that are stable.
Like apple, Shopify, amazon, crm, tsmc, xlnx etc....
Minimum requirement is that the company should be profitable for at least 4 quarters with 15% and above profit margin. These companies tend to rise slowly and steadily with time, so your longer expiration will give it time to play the senerio out 

A 10% rise in stock price will usually translate to a 20% options gain for u. And a 30% stick price increase will translate to a 50% gain for u.

Try to avoid meme stocks and new spac companies and volatile companies as their sudden movement downwards will mean much greater depreciation for your options also. Example, a 30% drop in share price will translate to a 50% drop in your options price.

Every leaps options I have bought till now will be profitable some point in time. U just need to prevent greed and exit accordingly.
Suggestion is to exit around the 50% profit mark or when the option is near the half way mark. Reason is that there is time decay associated with call options, so keeping it to expiry or keeping it too long is disadvantageous to you.

Best of luck!
